University of Pernambuco, Recife, 50760-901, Brazil. 

 

* Corresponding author. Almir Gonçalves Wanderley, Departamento de Fisiologia e 

Farmacologia, CCB, Universidade Federal de Pernambuco, Av. Prof. Moraes Rego, 

s/n, CEP: 50670-901- Cidade Universitária, Recife, PE, Brasil – Tel: 55-81-2126-8530, 

fax: 55-81-2126-8976. Email address: almirgw@globo.com 

94 
 



Abstract 

 

Aloe ferox Miller (Asphodelaceae) has been used to have anti-inflammatory, 

immunostimulant, anti-bacterial and anti-fungal, wound and burn healing, antitumor, 

and laxative activities. The extract of the resin from Aloe ferox (Af) was evaluated for 

its chronic toxicity (13 weeks) on hematological, biochemical and morphologic 

parameters in male and female Wistar rats. Oral treatment with Af 0.1, 0.5 and 1.5 g.kg-

1.day-1 (n = 12-13/group) failed, in both sexes, to changes body weight gain and food 

consumption, however was observed an increase in the consumption of water among the 

treated rats. The hematological examination showed that the animals treated with Af 

induced alterations in the erythrocytes, hemoglobin, hematocrit, platelets, MCV and 

RDW values. The biochemical analysis showed a reduction in creatinine, triglycerides, 

HDL, ALT and increase in the levels of alkaline phosphatase, total and indirect 

bilirrubin and LDL parameters in relation of the control group. The macroscopic 

examination of the viscera, encephalon and reproductive organs, as well as the absolute 

and relative weight of these organs presented changes in the treated groups. The main 

observed alterations were decrease of the spleen in females and of the small intestine in 

the males. In conclusion, the chronic oral administration of Aloe ferox resin extract 

induce significant alterations in several biochemical, hematological and morphological 

parameters in rats of both sexes, indicating that Aloe ferox exercises toxic effects on the 

organism of Wistar rats. 

 

Keywords: Aloe ferox Miller; Asphodelaceae; Chronic toxicity. 

 

95 
 



Introduction 

 

Aloe ferox is one of only a few plants depicted in San rock paintings (Reynolds, 

1950). The morphology of this species is characterized by persistent dry leaves on the 

lower portion of the single stem. The broad, fleshy leaves are dull green in summer or 

reddish-green in winter, with dark brown spines along the edges. They constitute a 

rather compact rosette arrangement around a stout stem (Palgrave, 1984) and aloe is 

well-known and famous for its medicinal qualities (Magwa, 2006). In Brazil, the largest 

producing of the plant are inside São Paulo (particularly in the municipal district of 

Jarinu), Santa Catarina and in the Northeast area. Being this last one, the one that 

possesses the best planting conditions (Magalhães, 2005).     

The bitter latex, tapped from the leaves by a traditional method and exported to 

Europe since 1761 (Marloth, 1915; Kruger and Beyers, 1977; Robertson, 1979; Forbes, 

1986; Wyk, 2008), is known commercially as “Cape aloes” (Escop, 2003). This plant is 

most widely used for its potent laxative and cathartic effects, attributed to 

anthraquinones and in particular aloe-emodin (Steenkampand and Stewart, 2007) in the 

leaf exudate. However, numerous other ethnomedicinal applications of the leaf exudate 

of Aloe ferox in southern Africa are known, such as relieving arthritis, anti-

inflammatory and anti-diabetics effects and, commonly, the use of leaf sap as eye drops 

for conjunctivitis and other eye ailments (Smith, 1888; Watt and Breyer-Brandwijk, 

1962; Crouch et al., 2006; Grace, 2008). The laxative effect is due to anthrone-C-

glycosides, of which aloin (syn. barbaloin) is the main compound (Wyk et al., 1995). 

Aloin occurs in tapped and dried leaf juice of Aloe ferox as a 1:1 mixture of aloin A and 

aloin B, at levels of about 10–28% dry weight (Wyk et al., 1995).  

 The modern research has shown that the Aloe ferox contains a chromone type 

natural ingredient, aloeresin, which is able to inhibit tyrosine at the cellular level 

without deterring cell viability. It is also shown to be a superior potent anti-oxidant with 

the Oxygen Radical Absorbance Capacity of 33 and 299 higher than green tea and grape 

seed extracts, respectively. It is also well documented that aloeresin promotes not only 

anti-aging by restoring the immune function in UV-damaged cells but also light 

sensitivity and naturally darker skin pigmentation without harmful chemicals or side 

effects (Jones et al., 2002). 

Cape aloe contains various carbohydrate constituents, such as polysaccharides 

and acemannan. Polysaccharides are known to have effective property in skin wound 

96 
 



repair. Polysaccharides fractions was capable to promote a cascade biological activities, 

including augmentation of reticuloendothelial function, modulation of immune 

responses, promotion of antiviral activity, and stimulation of hematopoiesis (Jia, 2008). 

Acemannan, a highly acetylated polymer of mannose, is known to induce the production 

of several inflammatory cytokines, some of which are thought to regulate wound 

healing (Barbul, 1990). In addition, acemannan can exert the antiviral and antitumoral 

activities in vivo via activation of macrophages, creation of NO and enhancement of 

cytotoxic T-lymphocytes (Lee et al., 2001; Choi and Chung, 2003).  

Topical administration of the whole leaf juice of Aloe ferox Miller, inhibit the 

growth of bacterial strains, such as Staphylococcus aureus, Klebsiella pneumoniae and 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa and are fungitoxic to Cryptococcus neoformans only (Jia, 

2008).  

 Although its use is widely spread, there is a lack of toxicological information 

detailed in the literature on this specie. Therefore, the aim of the present study was to 

assess the chronic toxicity of the Aloe ferox resin in Wistar rats.  

 

2. Material and Methods 

 

2.1. Preparation of the extract 

Aloe ferox resin was a commercial preparation, produced and supplied by Odaly 

Soares Laboratory, Ceará, Brazil. In the laboratory, the resin was powdered in automatic 

processor and dissolved in glycerin a.p (Vetec®) 40% (v/v). 

2.2. Animals 

Adult male and female Wistar rats (Rattus norvegicus var. albinus), aged 4-5 

months, weighing 300–350g and 250–300g, respectively, were obtained from 

Department of Physiology and Pharmacology at the Federal University of Pernambuco 

(UFPE). They were maintained in standard environmental conditions (22 ± 2ºC; 12:12 h 

dark/light cycle) and water and chow (Labina®, Purina, Brazil) were available ad 

libitum. The experimental protocol was approved to Ethical Committee in Animal 

Experimentation of of UFPE (Process no. 007340/2009-20), in accordance with the 

National Institute of Health Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals. 

 

 

 

97 
 



2.3. Chronic toxicity  

The method was performed according to the Organization for Economic Co-

Operation and Development (OECD) Test Guidelines with slightly modifications 

(OECD, 1981). Healthy rats of either sex were randomly divided into five groups by sex 

(13/group). Animals received glycerin 40%-vehicle orally (control group) or Aloe ferox 

resin with doses of 0.1, 0.5 or 1.5 g/kg/day for 12 consecutive weeks. Body weight was 

recorded weekly and food consumption and water intake were monitored daily. Animals 

were observed for signs of abnormalities during the treatment period. Toxic 

manifestations and mortality were monitored daily. At the end of each 4-weeks period, 

animals were fasted overnight, but allowed access to water ad libitum. They were then 

anesthetized with Nembutal® (0.035 g/kg, i.p.), and blood samples were obtained by 

retro-orbital puncture (Waynforth, 1980), using capillary tubes for hematological and 

biochemical studies, with and without anticoagulant ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid 

(EDTA), respectively.  

 
2.4. Hematological and biochemical analysis 

Hematological analysis was performed using an automatic hematological 

analyzer (Coulter STKS, Beckman). Parameters included: red blood cell (RBC) count, 

white blood cell (WBC) count, hemoglobin (Hb), hematocrit (Hct), mean corpuscular 

volume (MCV), mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH), mean corpuscular hemoglobin 

concentration (MCHC), red cell distribution width (RDW), platelets count and mean 

platelet volume (MPV). The differential leukocyte count was performed with an optical 

microscopy after staining and, in each case, 100 cells were counted. For biochemical 

analysis, blood was centrifuged at 1500×g for 10 min to obtain serum, which was stored 

at ?20 ?C until the following parameters were determined: glucose; blood urea nitrogen 

(BUN); creatinine; alkaline phosphatase, aspartate aminotransferase (AST); alanine 

aminotransferase (ALT); gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT); amylase; 

triglycerides; total cholesterol; high-density lipoproteins (HDL); low-density 

lipoproteins (LDL); total, direct and indirect bilirubin and albumine. Dosages were 

made using Architect (Abott®) automation with Boehringer Ingelheim® biochemical 

kits. 

98 
 



 2.5. Morphological study 
After sacrificed of animals by an excess of thiopental (0.140 g.kg-1, i.p.), 

necropsy was proceeded (n = 10/group) for analysis of the macroscopic external of 

heart, liver, spleen, lungs, kidney, adrenal gland, esophagus, stomach, smal intestine 

(fragment of 6–7 cm), hypophysis, hypothalamus, brain and reproductive organs (uterus 

and ovary or testicle, prostate, epididymis, seminal vesicle and vas deferens). These 

organs were carefully removed and weighed individually. Organ weights were 

expressed in terms absolute and relative (g and g.100g-1 of body weight, respectively). 

2.6. Statistical analysis 

Variance in data for body weights, food and water consumption, hematology, 

serum biochemistry and organ weights (both absolute and relative weights) was checked 

using one-way ANOVA followed by Tukey Comparison Test. P<0.05 was considered 

significant.  Statistical analyses were performed with the aid of the software GraphPad 

Prism 5®. 

 

3. Results 

 

 3.1. Chronic toxicity 

During 12 consecutives weeks of treatment by oral route with Aloe ferox at 

doses of 0.1, 0.5 and 1.5 g.kg-1, there were deaths among the females treated with the 

dose of 1.5 g.kg-1, among which 2 happened in the first month of treatment, 1 death in 

the 2nd month and 2 deaths in the 3rd month. Among the males treated by the same 

period of time, only one animal treaty with Aloe ferox 0.5 g.kg-1 and one treaty with 

Aloe ferox 1.5 g.kg-1 died during the second month of treatment. Days before the death 

of these encourages, toxicity signs were observed such an as abrupt weight loss and 

bending. 

No significant differences were found between the initial and final body weight 

of Aloe ferox treated rats and controls (Figures 1 and 2), however was observed an 

increase in the consumption of water among the treated rats (Figures 3 and 4) and no 

toxic effect was observed with the consumption of food throughout the period of 

investigation (Figure 5 and 6).  

99 
 



 3.2. Hematological and biochemical parameters 

The hematological profile of the treated and control groups are presented in 

Tables 1 to 6. For the females, Aloe ferox (1.5 g.kg-1group) induced a reduction in the 

values of erythrocytes (22.3%), hemoglobin (23.6%) and hematocrit (22.5%) and an 

increase in the value of RDW (39%) in relation to the group control in the first month of 

treatment. In the second month of treatment was observed an increase in the value of 

RDW (39.5%) with Aloe ferox (1.5 g.kg-1). Already in the third month of treatment with 

with the largest dose of Aloe ferox (1.5 g.kg-1group), the females presented an increase 

in the values of erythrocytes (10.3%), hemoglobin (13.9%), hematocrit (8.7%) and 

RDW (42.9%) in relation of the control group. For the males, Aloe ferox (1.5 g.kg-

1group) induced a reduction in the value of erythrocytes (15%) in relation to the group 

control in the first month of treatment. In the second month of treatment there were no 

statistically significant differences for the hematological parameters; and in the third 

month of treatment (1.5 g.kg-1group) the males presented a decrease in the value of 

platelets (12.6%) and an increase in the values of erythrocytes (10.3%), hemoglobin 

(13.9%) and hematocrit (8.7%) in relation of the control group.  

The biochemical profile of the treated and control groups are presented in Tables 

7 to 12. For the females, Aloe ferox (1.5 g.kg-1group) were observed a reduction in the 

values of creatinine (29%), triglyceride (40.7%) and high-density lipoprotein (HDL) 

(24.6%), while Aloe ferox 0.5 g.kg-1group presented a decrease in the values of total 

triglyceride (40.8%) and high-density lipoprotein (HDL) (20.6%) in relation to the 

control group in the first month of treatment. In the second month were observed an 

increase in the values of total bilirubin (49.6%), direct bilirubin (49.2%) and indirect 

bilirubin (57.1%) in the females treated with Aloe ferox 1.5 g.kg-1group; and in the third 

month of treatment there were no statistically significant differences for the biochemical 

parameters. For the males, Aloe ferox (1.5 g.kg-1group) induced a reduction of the value 

of creatinine (27.6%). Already in the second month was observed an increase of the 

values of alkaline phosphatase (58.0%) (0.5 g.kg-1group), total bilirubin (8.8%)(1.5 

g.kg-1group) and indirect bilirubin (74.3%)(1.5 g.kg-1group) in relation to the control 

group. In the third month of treatment, the males rats present an increase of alkaline 

phosphatase (46.5% and 88.5%)(0.5 and 1.5 g.kg-1groups respectively) and a decrease 

in the values of alanine aminotransferase (32.2%) (1.5 g.kg-1group). 

100 
 



 3.3. Morphological parameters 

The absolute tissue weights and external morphology macroscopic were altered 

by treatment with Aloe ferox Miller (Table 13 and Table 14). For the females treated 

with Aloe ferox (1.5 g.kg-1group) the absolute tissue weight was observed a decreased 

for spleen (45.8%). The relative tissue weights of the females was decreased for spleen 

(31.2%) and increased for brain (30.5%) and heart (11.4%). For the males treated with 

Aloe ferox (1.5 g.kg-1group) the absolute tissue weight were decreased for the small 

intestine (62.3%), brain (22.2%), prostate (38.8%) and lungs (29.9%). In relation to the 

relative weight, the male rats treated with Aloe ferox 1.5 g.kg-1g the relative weight were 

a decrease in the small intestine (56.6%). 

 

4. Discussion 

 The signs of systemic toxicity are defined from the reduction in body mass of 

animals experimental. Besides the reduction of development weight, the systemic 

toxicity is manifested through the reduction in consumption of water and food, changes 

behavior, apathy and poor condition of hair, as the presence of hair horrified (Mello, 

2001). Other signs of toxicity can be expressed by the change on the mass of bodies, 

hematological changes and biochemical blood (González and Silva, 2003). 

 In the chronic toxicity assay the Aloe ferox Miller extract resin was not well 

tolerated by oral route. The results indicate that administration of Aloe ferox produced 

clinical signs of toxicity and deaths for the 0.5 and 1.5 g.kg-1 treated groups. 

The rats treated with Aloe ferox presented a loss of corporal mass in the first 

month; this result is in agreement with previous reports of cathartic effects of ALOE 

(Ishii et al., 1994; Akao et al., 1996); however there were no statistical differences 

significant when compared to the group controls. Besides, that loss of corporal mass did 

not stay the following months of treatment. In what refers to the consumption of water, 

there was an increase of this consumption when compared the animals treated with the 

group control; this increase in the consumption of water is natural, due to the high 

defecation as a consequence of the laxative action of Aloe ferox. As for the ration 

consumption, there was not variation when compared the animals treated with the group 

control. The doses used in the present study represent one, five and fifteen teams the 

effective doses to exert laxative activity, found in previous studies in our laboratory.  

Analysis of blood parameters is relevant to risk evaluation as the changes in the 

hematological system have a higher predictive value for human toxicity, when the data 

101 
 



are translated from animal studies (Olson et al., 2000). The hematological examination 

showed that the animals treated with Aloe ferox reduced the quantify of erythrocytes for 

male and females, and hemoglobin and hematocrit for the males in the first month of 

treatment and elevation in the follow months, so that in the third month was observed an 

increase of that parameters in relation of the control group in both sexes (MATSUDA et 

al., 2008). Since there has been no report about relation between anemia and ALOE, 

dose-related decrease of hemoglobin, erythrocytes and hematocrit in females groups and 

decrease of erythrocytes for males was not explained. It is possible that the elevation of 

the hemoglobin, erythrocytes and hematocrit levels in the following months it is due to 

a hyperactivation of the hematopoietic system as defense of erythrocytes decrease in the 

first month of treatment. However, they are necessary studies more deepened for 

confirmation. 

In the biochemical analyses was observed that the animals treated with Aloe 

ferox Miller presented a reduction in the creatinine levels in the first month of treatment. 

Creatinine is found in the heart, skeletal muscle, brains and testes, but not in the liver. 

Elevated levels are found in muscular disorders, myocardial infarction and pulmonary 

disorders (Kaneko, 1989), however, reduced levels of creatinine do not present clinical 

meaning (Newhouse et al., 2008). The female rats also presented a reduction in the 

levels of HDL and triglycerides among the female groups treated with Aloe ferox; the 

decrease in triglyceride levels might represent a reduced lipid metabolism.   

 It is known that many toxic plants compounds accumulate in the liver where 

they are detoxified (Clarke and Clarke, 1977). A study of liver function tests may 

therefore prove useful in assessing especially the toxic effects of medicinal plants on the 

liver. These tests involve mainly determination of AST and ALT (Tilkian, 1979) and 

any marked necrosis of the liver cells lead to a significant rise of these enzymes in the 

blood serum. A small elevation in plasma bilirubin is an important indicator of liver 

damage in laboratory animals or could be a sign of biliary duct obstruction (Rasekh et 

al., 2008). In the second month of treatment with Aloe ferox were observed an increase 

in the values of total bilirubin, direct bilirubin and indirect bilirubin in the females 

treated with Aloe ferox, and an increase in the values of total bilirubin and indirect 

bilirubin for the males. This elevation remained following month of treatment, but this 

increase was not statistically significant compared to control. This way it is possible 

that Aloe ferox exercise hepatotoxic effect. 

102 
 



 Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is an important enzyme mainly derived from the 

liver, bones and in lesser amounts from intestines, placenta, kidneys and leukocytes. An 

increase in ALP levels in the serum is frequently associated with a variety of diseases. 

The three major underlying etiologies founded were obstructive biliary diseases, 

infiltrative liver diseases and sepsis (Friedman et al., 1996). Aloe ferox promoted an 

increase in alkaline phosphatase levels in males treated with doses of 0.5 and 1.5 g.kg-1, 

which from the previous data may be associated with liver disease. 

 The aminotransferases (AST and ALT) are well known enzymes used as 

biomarkers predicting possible toxicity (Rahman et al., 2001). Generally, damage to the 

parenchymal liver cells will result in elevations of both these aminotransferases (Wolf et 

al., 1972). However, Aloe ferox promoted a decrease in ALT levels in male rats in the 

third month of treatment, which is not clinically significant. 

 The macroscopic examination of the viscera, encephalon and reproductive 

organs, as well as the absolute and relative weight of these organs presented changes in 

the animals survived the treatment. With respect to females treated with aloe ferox, 

there was a reduction in absolute and relative mass of spleen; this shows a possible 

immunotoxic effect of Aloe ferox since the spleen plays a major role in immunological 

mechanisms (Laure  et al.; 2007). Moreover, it was observed an increase in the relative 

mass of hearth and brain. The increase in the hearth relative mass may indicate that 

Aloe ferox induces heart diseases, a hypothesis due to the increased RDW level found 

in females treated with Aloe ferox, which is also indicative of heart diseases. For the 

males treated with Aloe ferox was observed a decrease in the absolute tissue weight of 

brain, prostate, lungs and small intestine and a decrease in a relative weight of small 

intestine. This reduction in the relative and absolute of intestine can have the 

development of tumor in intestine, once that the continue use of anthraquinoids (present 

in Aloe species) can induce pseudomelanosis coli,a risck factor for colorectal neoplasma 

(Hara, 2008). 

In conclusion, the chronic oral administration of Aloe ferox resin extract induce 

significant alterations in several biochemical, hematological and morphological 

parameters in rats of both sexes, indicating that Aloe ferox exercises toxic effects on the 

organism of Wistar rats.

6.CONCLUSÃO 
 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

126 
 



 

6. CONCLUSÃO 

 

Com base nos resultados obtidos, pode-se concluir que o extrato da resina de 

Aloe ferox Miller quando administrado por via oral em ratos: 

 

 Exerceu atividade laxante em camundongos quando administrado nas doses 

de 0.05,0.1 and 0.2 g/kg; 

 
 Demonstrou após administração crônica (13 semanas) em ratos Wistar de 

ambos os sexos, efeitos tóxicos sobre os parâmetros bioquímicos, 

hematológicos e morfológicos.
